com.intel.fightclub.ui.common

Class TimeUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intel.fightclub.ui.common.TimeUtil

  • @ThreadSafe
public final class TimeUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility Class for Date & time manipulation

    • Method Detail

      • getStartOfDayEpochMillis

        public static long getStartOfDayEpochMillis(@NonNull
                                            java.util.Date date)
        Provides the time in milliseconds from the epoch for the start of the day of the provided date. ex: if input date corresponds to Jan 25th 14:00:00, the output milliseconds would correspond to Jan 25th 00:00:00.
        Parameters:
        date - the date to be converted
        Returns:
        time in milliseconds of the start of the day

      • getStartOfDayEpochMillis

        public static long getStartOfDayEpochMillis(long epochMillis)
        Provides the time in milliseconds from the epoch for the start of the day of the provided time in UTC milliseconds. ex: if input milliseconds corresponds to Jan 25th 14:00:00, the output milliseconds would correspond to Jan 25th 00:00:00.
        Parameters:
        epochMillis - UTC milliseconds from the epoch
        Returns:
        time in milliseconds of the start of the day

      • getEndOfDayInEpochMillis

        public static long getEndOfDayInEpochMillis(@NonNull
                                            java.util.Date date)
        Provides the time in milliseconds from the epoch for the end of the day of the provided date. ex: if input date corresponds to Jan 25th 14:00:00, the output milliseconds would correspond to Jan 25th 23:59:59.
        Parameters:
        date - the date to be converted
        Returns:
        time in milliseconds of the end of the day from the epoch

      • getEndOfDayInEpochMillis

        public static long getEndOfDayInEpochMillis(long epochMillis)
        Provides the time in milliseconds from the epoch for the end of the day of the provided date. ex: if input date corresponds to Jan 25th 14:00:00, the output milliseconds would correspond to Jan 25th 23:59:59.
        Parameters:
        epochMillis - UTC milliseconds from the epoch
        Returns:
        time in milliseconds of the end of the day from the epoch

      • getCalendarForStartOfDay

        @NonNull
public static java.util.Calendar getCalendarForStartOfDay(long epochMillis)
        Provides a calendar object for the provided time in milliseconds. The time for this calendar day is initialized to zero (start of the day) ex: if input milliseconds corresponds to Jan 25th 14:00:00, the output calendar would correspond to Jan 25th 00:00:00.
        Parameters:
        epochMillis - UTC milliseconds from the epoch
        Returns:
        the calendar object with time set to zero

      • getStartOfWeekEpochMillis

        public static long getStartOfWeekEpochMillis(@NonNull
                                             java.util.Date date)
        Provides the time in milliseconds from the epoch for start of the day of the first day of the week to which the provided date belongs to. ex: if input date corresponds to Mon 25 14:00:00 PST 2016, the output milliseconds would correspond to Sun Jan 24 00:00:00 PST 2016
        Parameters:
        date - the date to be used
        Returns:
        time in milliseconds

      • utcAnniversaryToLocalDate

        @NonNull
public static java.util.Date utcAnniversaryToLocalDate(@NonNull
                                                                java.util.Date utcDate)
        Converts a UTC anniversary date to local date. This should be used whenever we retrieve a date from PLTech's ProgramDefinition, since they return UTC anniversary dates, i.e. dates that only contain Day, Month, Year information and should not be converted using millis.
        Parameters:
        utcDate - A date in UTC as given by ARDA.
        Returns:
        A date in local time zone.

      • getDaysBetween

        public static int getDaysBetween(@NonNull
                                 java.util.Calendar day1,
                                 @NonNull
                                 java.util.Calendar day2)
        Method to reliably tell the distance in days between two dates. It takes into account leap years and daylight savings. Retrieved from: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20165564/calculating-days-between-two-dates-with-in-java
        Parameters:
        day1 - First day.
        day2 - Second day.
        Returns:
        The number of days in between given days, does not include the actual end date in the calculation.

      • getDaysBetween

        public static int getDaysBetween(@NonNull
                                 java.util.Date date1,
                                 @NonNull
                                 java.util.Date date2)
        Override of method #getDaysBetween(Calendar, Calendar) with dates instead of calendars. See that method for description.
        Parameters:
        date1 - first date
        date2 - second date
        See Also:
        getDaysBetween(Calendar, Calendar)

      • getAge

        public static int getAge(long birthdayEpochMillis)
        Calculates the age (number of years) from the provided birth time to current date
        Parameters:
        birthdayEpochMillis - birth date epoch milliseconds used for calculating age
        Returns:
        number of years as an integer

      • getAge

        public static int getAge(@NonNull
                         java.util.Date birthDate)
        Calculates the age (number of years) from the provided birth date to current date
        Parameters:
        birthDate - date used for calculating age
        Returns:
        number of years as an integer

        @NonNull
public static java.lang.CharSequence formatDurationShort(long durationSeconds)
        Converts the provided time in seconds into MM:SS or H:MM:SS format
        Parameters:
        durationSeconds - time in seconds to be formatted
        Returns:
        the formatted duration string

      • convertMillisToStopwatchString

        @NonNull
public static java.lang.String convertMillisToStopwatchString(long millis)
        Converts an elapsed time in milliseconds to a "stopwatch" style formatted time (e.g., 00:32:12.999).
        Parameters:
        millis - An elapsed time in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        A formatted string with the "stopwatch" style formatted time.

        public static java.lang.String formatDayTime(@NonNull
                                             android.content.Context context,
                                             int hours,
                                             int minutes)
        Format time of the day in hours:minutes format using current locale, including 12/24 format
        Parameters:

        Returns:
